The release resulted in one (1) employee or contractor fatality, one (1) employee or contractor injury, approximately $2.1 million in onsite property damage and no other onsite or offsite impacts.  Wynnewood revised confined space entry and safe work permitting procedures, and trained employees as a result of the incident.

5 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Wynnewood maintains a written emergency response program to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program includes procedures for responding to a loss of containment, including the possibility of a fire or explosion is a flammable substance is accidentally releases. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuations plans an accounting for personnel, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post incident management. Additionally, the refinery has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. The emergency response program is updated when necessary. Wynnewood's program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations. 

Wynnewood coordinates its emergency response program and response actions with the Garvin County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). This coordination includes quarterly meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives. In addition to quarterly LEPC meetings, the refinery participates in emergency drills conducted by the LEPC that involve area emergency responders. The refinery has 24/7

mmables, Wynnewood has adopted several API, NFPA, insurance company, ASME, ANSI, and other codes and standards.

Uniform Prevention Activities
The accident prevention program is applied throughout the RMP-covered processes. These prevention programs are designed and implemented to prevent potential accidental release scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and/or human errors.

Specialized Safety Features
Safety features are incorporated into the design, construction, operation and maintenance of the processes to help prevent, quickly detect and control a release, and to reduce the consequences of a release. The following types of safety features are used in the covered processes:

Release Detection
- Hydrocarbon, hydrogen sulfide, and hydrofluoric acid detectors and alarms
Release Containment and Control
- Process relief valves that discharge to flares to capture and/or incinerate episodic releases
- Remote Valves for safe isolation of the process (manual or automated)
Automatic shutdown systems for specific process
Curbs or dikes to contain liquid releases
Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system)
Total plant emergency shutdown (ESD) Plan
Camera monitoring in the Alky area
Release Mitigation
- Fire suppression and extinguishing systems
- Deluge system for specific equipment
- Trained on-site emergency response organization
- Hand-held and wheeled cart fire extinguishers
- Personal protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus, etc.).
Blast-resistant buildings to help protect personnel and control systems

4 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Wynnewood Refinery has an excellent record of accident prevention. Wynnewood conducts formal incident investigations to identify and correct the identified causes of the events that do not meet the EPA definition of an RMP incident.  

An accidental release occurred May 23, 2023, from the Prime G Unit that con

ated substances in the process, and other process changes are properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Reviews ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and to verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process-operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate a change. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are notified of changes and, if necessary, trained on the changes.

Incident Investigation
Wynnewood promptly investigates all incidents that result in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to gather the facts, determine the root cause, and develop corrective action for the prevention of the same or a similar incident. Findings and recommendations are documented and are forwarded to refinery management for resolution.

Compliance Audits
Wynnewood periodically conducts audits to determine the implementation of the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program. Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years.
An audit team develops findings that are forwarded to refinery management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until resolution. The resolution of each finding is documented. The two most recent audit reports are retained.

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
Hazards in the processes are continually managed to ensure safe operations. The existing safety features to prevent accidental releases of regulated substances in the refinery are described below.

For toxic substances, Wynnewood has reviewed and adopted industry guidelines and manufacturer's recommendations regarding safe storage and handling. This includes personnel training as well as robust equipment designs. For fla

ce. This review provides an additional check that construction is in accordance with design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. The PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves as a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

Mechanical Integrity
Wynnewood has practices and procedures for maintaining process equipment at the refinery. The aspects of this program include: (1) training; (2) written procedures; (3) performing inspections and tests; (4) correcting identified equipment deficiencies; and (5) applying quality assurance measures. These activities form a system to maintain the mechanical integrity of the processes.

Wynnewood incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps to ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.

Safe Work Practices
Wynnewood has safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and safety. Examples of these include: (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel; (2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance; (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous substances before process piping and equipment is opened; (4) a permit and procedure to control sparkproducing activities (i.e., hot work); and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space. These procedures, along with training of affected personnel, form a system to ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely at the refinery.

Management of Change
Wynnewood has comprehensive system to manage change to the processes at the refinery. Changes to process equipment, technology (including process-operating conditions), procedures, changes to the quantity of regul

ng
Wynnewood has a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating the processes at the refinery. New employees receive training in refinery process operations. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted at least every three years. All training is documented for each operator including the means to verify that the operator understood the training.

Contractors
Wynnewood uses contractors to supplement its workforce and during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the refinery has procedures in place to ensure that contractors: (1) perform their work in a safe manner; (2) have appropriate knowledge and skills; (3) are aware of the hazards of their workplace; (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency; (5) understand and follow site-specific safety rules; and (6) inform refinery personnel of any hazards that they find while performing their work. This is accomplished by providing contractors with an orientation session that covers: (1) a process overview; (2) information about the safety and health hazards; (3) emergency response plan requirements; and (4) safe work practices prior to beginning their work. In addition, Wynnewood evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the contractor selection process. Wynnewood personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.

Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)
Wynnewood conducts a PSSR on any new process or process modification that requires a change in process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into servi

necessary. Employees are encouraged to discuss accident prevention with their supervisors and to bring any questions, comments or suggestions forward for open discussion.

Process Safety Information
Complete and accurate written process safety information concerning process chemicals, process technology, and process equipment is essential to an effective accident prevention program, as well as completing and maintaining a process hazard analysis. The process safety information is readily available to all employees and used by refinery personnel, the process hazard analysis team, and persons in charge of updating the emergency response plan. Wynnewood maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to maintain safe operations. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters, specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis and configuration. Chemical specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in Safety Data Sheets (SDS).

Wynnewood also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment at the refinery. This information includes, but is not limited to, materials of construction, design pressure ratings, temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment. This information in combination with written procedures and trained personnel provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and refinery changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
The refinery has a comprehensive program to ensure that hazards associated with the processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, the process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.  

Wynnewood prim

s subject to Program 1 requirements per the U.S. EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Risk Management Program.
In 2022, Wynnewood Refining Company, LLC made changes to the site’s existing Hydrocracker Unit to allow the unit to process renewable feedstock (i.e. soybean oil, plant oils, or animal fats) in addition to feedstocks generated from crude oil.  This allowed the unit to convert a renewable feedstock into distillate fuel.  Processing of the non-petroleum feedstock occurs at the existing Hydrocracker / Renewable Diesel Unit (Hydrocracker/RDU).

3 GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Wynnewood has implemented an accidental release prevention program. The accidental release prevention program required for Program 3 processes is summarized as follows:

Employee Participation
Active employee participation and involvement in the development and implementation of the refinery's accident prevention program is a critical component of the overall objective to prevent or minimize the consequences of a catastrophic release of a flammable or toxic substance. Employee involvement helps to ensure that all perspectives regarding accident prevention are considered for implementation. Open communications are encouraged between supervisors and employees regarding all aspects of safety and health issues concerning employees, contractors and the public.

Wynnewood strongly promotes employee involvement in safety issues through, for example, regularly scheduled safety meetings, tail gate safety meetings, hazard communications, safety suggestions, incident reporting system, and special training programs such as emergency response training and first aid training.  Wynnewood actively seeks employee involvement in the development and implementation of all accident prevention activities through the appropriate programs.  Accident prevention is discussed at the regularly scheduled safety meetings and/or during special training sessions, if

Wynnewood Refining Company, LLC
Wynnewood, Oklahoma
Risk Management Plan – November 2023

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The Wynnewood Refining Company, LLC has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety and protecting the environment. 
The commitment stems from our core values:
     -      Safety
     -      Environment
     -      Integrity
     -      Corporate Citizenship
     -      Continuous Improvement
all which play a vital role in the way we operate our refinery and the decisions that we make.
This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, including training of personnel and safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the processes at the Wynnewood Refinery (Wynnewood). Wynnewood implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. Wynnewood places emphasis on prevention, prompt detection, and expeditious correction of unsafe conditions by periodically conducting internal inspection and regularly training responsible personnel. Should a release occur, the refinery's trained personnel will respond to control, contain, and mitigate the release.

2 STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Wynnewood operates a variety of processes to produce petroleum products from crude oil, such as gasoline, diesel, jet fuel, hydrocarbon solvents, and liquefied petroleum gases. The refinery has a threshold quantity of several flammable substances and one toxic substance (hydrogen fluoride). Regulated flammable substances at the refinery include butane, isobutane, isopentane, propane, propylene, and flammable mixtures of various regulated flammable substances. The refinery includes a total of twelve (12) RMP-covered processes. The refinery is subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation.
